options.label: B

title: What causes yeast infections, and how do you get rid of them? - Liesbeth Demuyser

options.label: B
options.text: Fungi that produce an enzyme to raise the vagina's pH.

options.label: C
options.text: Viruses that produce a toxin to lower the vagina's pH.

options.label: D
options.text: Protozoa that produce a hormone to raise the vagina's pH.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the yeast species that is the usual culprit of vaginal thrush or yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: The pH increases and there are fewer microbes to compete with.

options.label: B
options.text: The pH decreases and there are more microbes to compete with.

options.label: C
options.text: The pH remains the same and there are no changes in the balance.

options.label: D
options.text: The pH increases and there are more microbes to compete with.

options.label: A
options.text: The immune cells rushing to the site.

options.label: B
options.text: The Candida cells permeating the tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: The epithelial cells lining the vagina being degraded.

options.label: D
options.text: The hyphae forming in the vagina.

multiple-choice.question: What can make people more susceptible to vaginal yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Antifungal medications reduce the number of Candida cells, allowing the immune system and other microorganisms to regain control.

options.label: B
options.text: Antifungal medications increase the number of Candida cells, allowing the immune system and other microorganisms to be overwhelmed.

options.label: C
options.text: Antifungal medications have no effect on Candida cells, allowing the immune system and other microorganisms to continue to fight the infection.

options.label: D
options.text: Antifungal medications only work on the symptoms of yeast infections, not the underlying cause.

multiple-choice.question: What is a preliminary study that has shown promise in keeping Candida in check while reducing inflammation?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of probiotics containing harmless yeasts.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of antibiotics to kill Candida cells.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of antifungal medications to reduce Candida cells.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of a new type of yeast to treat yeast infections.

multiple-choice.question: Why do some people experience recurrent yeast infections, and what is currently unclear about the cause of these infections?

options.label: A
options.text: The cause seems to be genetic, and the immune system is unable to recognize and regulate Candida cells.

options.label: B
options.text: The cause seems to be hormonal changes and diet, and the immune system is unable to keep up with the changes.

options.label: C
options.text: The cause seems to be semen and tight, non-breathable garments, and the immune system is unable to prevent the infections.

options.label: D
options.text: The cause is currently unclear, and requires a lot more research.

title: What’s the best country to live in?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) metric?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the overall well-being of a country's citizens.

options.label: B
options.text: To gauge the size of an economy in a single, easy-to-understand number.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the country with the best food.

options.label: D
options.text: To estimate the country's life expectancy.

multiple-choice.question: What does GDP per capita take into account?

options.label: A
options.text: The total GDP divided by the number of people living in that country, as well as the country's environmental burdens.

options.label: B
options.text: The total GDP divided by the number of people living in that country.

options.label: C
options.text: The country's life expectancy, health, and education.

options.label: D
options.text: The country's income per capita and environmental sustainability.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a more accurate estimate of a country's GDP.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more time-consuming and complex.

options.label: A
options.text: Health, education, and income per capita

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is too complex and time-consuming.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to the needs of the country.

options.label: D
options.text: This question is subjective and depends on individual priorities.

multiple-choice.question: B: To gauge the size of an economy in a single, easy-to-understand number.

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to a person who teleported from sea level to the top of Mt. Everest?

options.label: A
options.text: They would experience a significant increase in oxygen levels in the air.

options.label: B
options.text: They would likely suffocate in minutes due to the low oxygen levels.

options.label: C
options.text: They would experience a significant decrease in barometric pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: They would experience no changes in their body.

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to a person's body in just one month that allows them to endure high altitude?

options.label: A
options.text: Their heart rate and breathing slow down.

options.label: C
options.text: Their body adapts to the high altitude by increasing the concentration of hemoglobin and the rate and depth of breathing.

options.label: D
options.text: Their body becomes less efficient at transporting oxygen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the condition that occurs when a person ascends to altitudes above 2,500 meters and experiences oxygen deprivation?
What is the name of the condition that occurs when a person's body adapts to high altitude by increasing the concentration of hemoglobin and the rate and depth of breathing?
What is the name of the condition that occurs when a person's smallest blood vessels, called capillaries, leak and fluid builds up in the brain or lungs?
What is the name of the genetic advantage that some Tibetans and South Americans have that can prevent minor altitude sickness?

What is the name of the condition that occurs when a person's body adapts to high altitude by increasing the concentration of hemoglobin and the rate and depth of breathing, but also increases the risk of fluid buildup in the brain and lungs?
What is the name of the process by which a person's body adapts to high altitude by increasing the concentration of plasma in their blood?
What is the name of the process by which a person's body adapts to high altitude by increasing the concentration of hemoglobin?
What is the name of the process by which a person's body adapts to high altitude by increasing the rate and depth of breathing?

title: The British Museum is full of stolen artifacts

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Nearly half of the artifacts have disputed ownership.

options.label: D
options.text: The museum does not have enough funding to acquire new artifacts.

options.label: B
options.text: To acquire precious resources and wealth from other countries.

options.label: C
options.text: To establish trade routes and exchange goods with other countries.

options.label: D
options.text: To establish colonies and settle new lands.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They are a collection of bronze sculptures created by the Benin kingdom in present-day Nigeria.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a collection of bronze sculptures created by the ancient Egyptians.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a collection of bronze sculptures created by the ancient Greeks.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Benin punitive expedition in 1897?

options.label: A
options.text: The British soldiers were defeated and forced to retreat.

options.label: B
options.text: The British soldiers conquered the city and burned it to the ground.

options.label: C
options.text: The British soldiers were able to negotiate a peaceful resolution with the Benin kingdom.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the current stance of the British Museum regarding the return of cultural property?

options.text: The museum is committed to returning all cultural property to its rightful owners.

options.label: B
options.text: The museum is restricted by a government act that prevents it from returning objects.

options.label: C
options.text: The museum is willing to lend cultural property to other institutions, including those in Nigeria.

options.label: D
options.text: The museum is not interested in returning cultural property.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Benin dialogue group?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a group of British soldiers who fought in the Benin punitive expedition.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a group of Nigerian artists who created the Benin bronzes.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a group of western museums and Nigerian government representatives who are discussing potential solutions for the return of cultural property.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a group of British museum curators who are studying the Benin bronzes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with the legacy of colonial power?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legacy of centuries of colonial power that repeats itself again and again with different artifacts in different museums.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a legacy of centuries of colonial power that only affects the British Museum.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a legacy of centuries of colonial power that only affects the Benin kingdom.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a legacy of centuries of colonial power that only affects the ancient Egyptians.

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What happened to a parrot that went missing with its owner in 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: It was adopted by another family.

options.label: B
options.text: It was sold to a pet store.

options.label: C
options.text: It lost its British accent and was reunited with its owner four years later.

options.label: D
options.text: It was injured in a storm.

multiple-choice.question: Why do parrots use contact calls?

options.label: B
options.text: To form social bonds with their owners.

options.label: C
options.text: To interact and stay in touch with other parrots.

options.label: D
options.text: To warn other parrots of potential threats.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the syrinx of parrots?

options.label: D
options.text: It is located at the top of their windpipe.

multiple-choice.question: How do parrots shape sounds using their tongues and beaks?

options.label: A
options.text: By moving their tongues quickly in and out.

options.label: B
options.text: By moving their beaks up and down.

multiple-choice.question: What is special about the brains of parrots?

options.label: D
options.text: They have a different type of brain.

multiple-choice.question: What did a lost parrot manage to do to get back home?

options.label: B
options.text: It repeated its full name and address.

options.label: D
options.text: It flew back on its own.

multiple-choice.question: Why do captive parrots talk?

options.label: B
options.text: To form social bonds with their owners.

options.label: C
options.text: To warn other parrots of potential threats.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the African grey parrot that posed an existential question?
What is the main reason why wild parrot populations have decreased dramatically?
Why is it essential to study parrots in the wild?
